wikipedia_page.main: George Talbot FES (26 October 1882 – 13 April 1952) was an English entomologist who specialised in butterflies. He wrote about 150 scientific papers, the majority being primarily systematic, consisting of the description of new species or the revision of various genera. He was also responsible for the curation and preservation of the Joicey collection of Lepidoptera prior to its accession by the Natural History Museum.

George Talbot in The Fauna of British India, Including Ceylon and Burma (1939) provides some interesting detail:
George Talbot may refer to:
*George Talbot, 4th Earl of Shrewsbury (c. 1468–1538)
*George Talbot, 6th Earl of Shrewsbury (1528–1590), English statesman
*George Talbot, 9th Earl of Shrewsbury (1566–1630), Roman Catholic priest
*Sir George Talbot, 3rd Baronet (1761–1850), English cricketer
*George Talbot (judge) (1861–1938), Judge of the High Court of Justice
*George Talbot (entomologist) (1882–1952), English entomologist who specialised in butterflies
*George Talbot (New Zealand cricketer) (1907–1943), New Zealand cricketer

Joicey employed specialist entomologists including George Talbot to curate his collection and financed numerous expeditions throughout the world to obtain previously unknown varieties. More than 190 scientific articles were produced during the active period of the Hill Museum. This body of research was described as "a contribution to the study of the exotic Lepidoptera of very great scientific value".

He acquired the Henley Grose-Smith collection in 1910. Two years later he bought the Herbert Druce collection. To house his growing collection, he founded the Hill Museum at his Witley home in 1913. Joicey employed curators, including Alfred Noakes (from 1906) and George Talbot (from 1915), with a staff of assistants.

According to George Talbot (Fauna of British India) the race anomala is found in the western Himalayas while the nominate form is from the eastern Himalayas.

Stygionyx is a monotypic moth genus of the family Erebidae erected by George Hampson in 1926. Its only species, Stygionyx montana, was first described by James John Joicey and George Talbot in 1917. It is found in New Guinea.
Barlowia is a genus of moths in the subfamily Lymantriinae. The genus was erected by George Talbot in 1929.
Amata mjobergi is a species of moth in the family Erebidae first described by George Talbot in 1926. It is found on Borneo.

Trabala viridana, the Sunda green Vishnu-moth, is a moth of the family Lasiocampidae. The species was first described by James John Joicey and George Talbot in 1917. It is found in Sumatra, Borneo and Peninsular Malaysia.

Ambulyx ceramensis is a species of moth in the family Sphingidae. It was described by James John Joicey and George Talbot in 1921 and is known from Indonesia.
Clanis pratti is a species of moth of the family Sphingidae first described by James John Joicey and George Talbot in 1921. It is known from Sulawesi and surrounding islands in Indonesia.

Charaxes defulvata is a butterfly in the family Nymphalidae. It is found on the island of São Tomé. The habitat consists of forests. The species of butterfly was named by James John Joicey and George Talbot in 1926.
Category:Taxa named by George Talbot (entomologist)

Charaxes lemosi is a butterfly in the family Nymphalidae. The species was described by James John Joicey and George Talbot in 1927.Four new butterflies from the island of St. Principe. Joicey, J.J. & Talbot, G. Entomologist (1927) 60: 12-16 It is found on the island of Príncipe. The habitat consists of forests.

Charaxes antiquus is a butterfly in the family Nymphalidae. It is found on the island of São Tomé.Afrotropical Butterflies: File H - Charaxinae - Tribe Charaxini The habitat consists of forests and woodland. The species was named by James John Joicey and George Talbot in 1926.
Charaxes barnsi is a butterfly in the family Nymphalidae. It is found on the island of Príncipe. The species was named by James John Joicey and George Talbot in 1927.
